toolbar.button.language.name: Language
toolbar.button.language.note:
Select a different translation from the 'lang' folder.
Then the application will restart.
toolbar.button.language.note.single:
---
Unfortunately, there is only one translation file. :(
toolbar.button.about.name: About
toolbar.button.about.about:
This application allows you to search through the possible Pokémon that you can face in the Battle Frontier in Platinum, HeartGold, and SoulSilver.
Check the Help for more info.

If an error occurs, check the log files in the ‘logs’ folder.

Click the 'Damage Calculator' button to copy the link to Pokémon Showdown's damage calculator to your clipboard.
toolbar.button.help.name: Frontier Help
toolbar.button.help.tooltip: Learn the mechanics of the Battle Frontier
toolbar.button.sources.name: Sources
toolbar.button.sources.sources:
Data for this program was sourced mainly from the Smogon forums and Bulbapedia.
If you find any errors, please let me know!

Click the 'Source Links' button to copy a list of source links to your clipboard.
help:
Choose a topic. It's recommended to read them in order.

You can navigate with 'Tab' and select with 'Space'.
Press 'Escape' to close the current window.
help.basics.info:
The Battle Frontier has five facilities. Each has slightly different rules. Win many battles in row and defeat the Frontier Brains to earn Prints on your Frontier Record!

Battle Tower:
Face opposing trainers in 3v3 battles. Win 7 battles in a row to advance.

Battle Arcade:
Face opposing trainers in 3v3 battles. Win 7 battles in a row to advance. Pokémon can't bring items. Before each battle, play the game board for a random effect.

Battle Castle:
Face opposing trainers in 3v3 battles. Win 7 battles in a row to advance. Your Pokémon can't bring items. Your Pokémon are not healed between battles. Earn Castle Points by defeating your opponent handily, and spend them to heal your Pokémon, give your Pokémon held items, etc.

Battle Factory:
Face opposing trainers in 3v3 battles. Win 7 battles in a row to advance. Instead of using your own Pokémon, choose rental Pokémon in Level 50 or Open Level modes. You can trade a Pokémon with a defeated opponent.

Battle Hall:
Face opposing trainers in 1v1 battles. Choose what type of Pokémon you will face, and that type will be stronger next time. Win 10 battles in a row to advance. You must use the same species of Pokémon for the entire challenge.

Every facility also has Double Battle and Multi Battle modes. However, you won't face the Frontier Brain in these modes.
help.nonhall.pokemon.info:
There are 400 species of Pokémon in the Battle Tower/Arcade/Castle/Factory.
Many have multiple possible moves and stats, making a total of 950 different sets you can encounter.
help.nonhall.groups.info.1:
It's useful to separate sets into groups.
There are 4 main groups of sets. I call them the A, B, C, and D groups.
This table describes the 4 main groups:
help.nonhall.groups.info.2: A Pokémon may have more than 1 possible set. The number of sets a Pokémon has depends on their group.
help.nonhall.groups.info.3: Later sets are usually stronger and have more offensive moves than earlier sets. For example, Aggron 1 knows Sandstorm and Screech, while Aggron 4 knows Stone Edge and Earthquake. This isn't always true, though.
help.nonhall.groups.tree.name: Group
help.nonhall.groups.a.name: Group A
help.nonhall.groups.b.name: Group B
help.nonhall.groups.c.name: Group C
help.nonhall.groups.d.name: Group D
help.nonhall.streaks.info.1:
As you progress through a facility, you'll face Pokémon from stronger groups. Before battle 50, the seventh battle of each round is slightly stronger.
Most facilities use the following progression:
help.nonhall.streaks.info.2: Once you reach battle 50, you'll be able to face a wide variety of sets, as well as Legendary Pokémon:
help.nonhall.streaks.info.3: The Battle Factory's Open Level mode follows a different progression. It skips the early rounds where you face weak Pokémon, and Legendary Pokémon start appearing earlier.
help.nonhall.trainers.info.1:
Trainers are what actually determine the Pokémon you'll face.
In the Battle Tower/Arcade/Castle, trainers use a particular selection of Pokémon that generally match their trainer class.
For example: Fishermen use Water-type Pokémon; Bird Keepers use Flying-type Pokémon; and PIs use Pokémon that know Destiny Bond, Explosion, or OHKO moves.
In the Battle Factory, trainers can use any Pokémon in the groups they've been assigned.

Trainers also determine the IVs of the Pokémon you face. IVs slowly increase as you progress, then jump to 31 once you reach battle 50. At that point, you'll usually face trainers with 31 IVs, but there are occasionally trainers at the next highest IV.
In the Battle Tower/Arcade/Castle:
help.hall.pokemon.info:
There are 477 species of Pokémon in the Battle Hall.
Every Pokémon has just one possible set.
help.hall.groups.info:
It's useful to separate sets into groups.
There are 4 groups of sets. They're based on the Base Stat Total of the Pokémon.
help.hall.level.info:
The level of the opposing Pokémon depends on your Pokémon's level, the rank you're challenging, and the number of types that are at rank 2 or higher.

At the beginning of a Battle Hall challenge, opposing Pokémon may be 20-30 levels lower then your Pokémon.
By the end of a Battle Hall challenge, opposing Pokémon will be at nearly the same level.

Hall Matron Argenta's Pokémon are always the same level as yours.
help.hall.rank.info.1:
As you progress through the Battle Hall, you'll face Pokémon from stronger groups.
The Pokémon you may face depend on the rank you're challenging:
help.hall.rank.info.2: You'll face Hall Matron Argenta at certain battle milestones. She can use a wide variety of Pokémon:
help.hall.rank.info.3:
The IVs of the opposing Pokémon also depend on rank.
They start at 8 and increase by 2 each rank.
help.hall.rank.info.4: Hall Matron Argenta's Pokémon always have 31 IVs.
help.mechanics.arcade.board.info:
Before each battle, you'll play the game board to see what happens.
Black boxes affect your team, red boxes affect the opponent's team, and gray boxes affect the field or have other effects. Certain effects only appear at higher win streaks.
Also, if you don't stop the game board in 30 seconds, it stops on its own.
help.mechanics.arcade.board.tree.targete: Affects either your team (black) or your opponent's team (red)
help.mechanics.arcade.board.tree.berry: Give all Pokémon a random Berry
help.mechanics.arcade.board.tree.item: Give all Pokémon a random item
help.mechanics.arcade.board.tree.level_u: Level up all Pokémon by 3 levels
help.mechanics.arcade.board.tree.random: The game board will move randomly next battle
help.mechanics.castle.earning_points.inf:
At the start of each round, you receive 10 Castle Points.
After a battle, you'll receive Castle Points depending on how well you did:
help.mechanics.castle.earning_points.tre: for each of your Pokémon that aren't fainted
for each of your Pokémon with full HP
for each of your Pokémon between half and full HP
for each of your Pokémon with less than half HP
for each of your Pokémon with no status ailments
for each opposing Pokémon that was leveled up
if you used 5 PP or less
if you used between 6 and 10 PP
if you used between 11 and 15 PP
help.mechanics.castle.spending_points.in:
Castle Points can be spent on options like recovering your Pokémon's health, learning about the opponent's Pokémon, and renting items.
Initially, you won't have many options, but you can spend points to rank up and unlock more. Castle Points and rank ups carry over between rounds, but purchased items will be lost.

Recovery options:
After battle 21, you unlock the "Pass" option, which lets you skip a battle entirely.
help.mechanics.castle.spending_points.tr: View a Pokémon's stats and item
help.mechanics.factory.trading.info:
As you know, the Battle Factory lets you trade one of your Pokémon for a Pokémon you just defeated. The Record Machine displays how many trades you've done in a run. Note that choosing rentals at the start of a round increases this number as well.

The more you trade, the better your rental Pokémon will be at the start of the next round.
Every 7 trades gets you one "better" Pokémon. That means a Pokémon in the next group (for example, C2 instead of C1) and with a higher IV (for example, 12 instead of 8). This can be especially helpful in the early rounds of Level 50 mode. See the 'About Streaks' and 'About Trainers' topics.
help.mechanics.factory.clauses.info:
Just like every other facility in the Battle Frontier, the Battle Factory follows Species Clause and Item Clause. Also, the opposing team is generated before you choose to trade. This has a few consequences for what Pokémon you can face.

Species Clause means that you can't have two Pokémon of the same species on your team. Therefore:
-You will never face a species on your team.
-You will never face a species you faced in the previous battle.
-At the start of a round, you will never face one of the species you could have chosen.

Item Clause means that you can't have two Pokémon holding the same item on your team. Therefore:
-You will never face a set that holds the same item as any of your Pokémon.
-You will never face a set that holds the same item as any of the sets you faced in the previous battle.
-At the start of a round, you will never face a set that holds an item that any of the sets you could have chosen are holding.

This information can sometimes allow you to figure out an opposing Pokémon's set by eliminating the other possibilities.

page.welcome.name: Start Page
page.welcome.welcome:
Welcome. Click the button below to load data.
Once completed, additional tabs will appear on the top.
page.all_sets.name: Browse Sets
page.all_sets.tooltip: Browse all Battle Tower/Arcade/Castle/Factory Pokémon sets.
page.all_sets.info:
This page lets you browse all the possible Pokémon sets in the Battle Tower/Arcade/Castle/Factory.
Select a Pokémon and a set number from the dropdown menus and have a look at the set!
page.all_sets.ivBox.tooltip.fixed: The IV cannot be changed for these sets.
page.all_sets_by_trainer.name: Sets by Trainer
page.all_sets_by_trainer.tooltip: View Pokémon sets organized by opposing trainers for the Battle Tower/Arcade/Castle.
page.all_sets_by_trainer.info:
This page groups Pokémon sets by trainer for the Battle Tower/Arcade/Castle/Factory. Each trainer uses a particular selection of Pokémon.
Select a battle number, a trainer class, a trainer name, and then have a look at their Pokémon!
page.all_sets_by_trainer.darach:
Note:
Castle Valet Darach chooses which set number to use for all his Pokémon when the battle starts.
For example: he may have only set 1 Pokémon or only set 2 Pokémon, but never a mix of the two.
page.all_sets_by_trainer.thorton:
Note:
Missing data for Factory Head Thorton!
The listed Pokémon are placeholders!
page.generic.result.abilities: This Pokémon's ability may be {0} or {1}.
page.generic.facility.arcade.tooltip:
Pokémon can't bring held items.
You get a preview of the opponent's team before each battle.
page.generic.facility.castle.tooltip: Your Pokémon can't bring held items, but opposing Pokémon can.
page.generic.facility.factory_50.tooltip:
Pokémon have different IVs.
Trainers aren't limited to their normal roster of Pokémon.
Pokémon are level 50.
Early rounds have weak Pokémon.
page.generic.facility.factory_open.toolt:
Pokémon have different IVs.
Trainers aren't limited to their normal roster of Pokémon.
Pokémon are level 100.
Early rounds have strong Pokémon.
page.search.name: Search Sets
page.search.tooltip: Figure out what you're battling against in the Battle Tower/Arcade/Castle.
page.search.info:
This page allows you to search through each individual Pokémon owned by each trainer in the Battle Tower/Arcade/Castle/Factory.
Many trainers have the exact same sets, so only unique results are shown.
page.search.searchButton.sure:
You haven't selected any search terms.
The search will gather every possible set, which may cause the program to stop responding for a short time.
Click 'OK' or press 'Space' if you want to continue.
page.search.resultsBox.done: Search done: {0} sets found, {1} of which are unique.
page.search.resultsBox.trainerInfo.singu: Found {0} trainer that can use this set.
page.search.resultsBox.trainerInfo.plura: Found {0} trainers that can use this set.
page.search.result.none: No results! Try a different search.
page.hall_sets.name: Browse Hall Sets
page.hall_sets.tooltip: Browse all Battle Hall Pokémon sets.
page.hall_sets.info:
This page lets you browse all the possible Pokémon sets in the Battle Hall.
Select a Pokémon from the dropdown menu and have a look at the set!
page.hall_calc.name: Hall Sets by Type/Rank
page.hall_calc.tooltip: View Battle Hall Pokémon sets organized by type and rank.
page.hall_calc.info:
This page groups Battle Hall Pokémon sets by which type and rank they can appear in.
Put in your Pokémon's level and BST, select a type and rank, and then have a look at the possible Pokémon!
page.hall_calc.your_bst.tooltip:
In her Silver Print battle, Hall Matron Argenta will use a Pokémon in the same BST range as yours.
That's the only reason this box is here.
page.hall_calc.type.tooltip: You can also select Hall Matron Argenta here.
page.hall_calc.visited_types: Number of Types at Rank 2 or higher:
page.hall_calc.levelBox.tooltip.fixed: The level cannot be changed for these sets.
